channel.title: Pre Calculus help
channel.description:
I started the year getting so so grades in Honors PreCalc, and I have a chance to make up for it by doing extra credit.
URL to problem: http://www.geocities.com/duranko@verizon.net/honprec_a2_wk1_2.htm
The extra credit is insane, because I don't know how to do it. The problem of the week is at this URL. Can anyone help? The extra credit is due tomorrow: Friday, September 15.
I know what a third degree polynomial is. It's like... f(x) = f(x) = 5x[sup]3[/sup] + 2x[sup]2[/sup] + 8x + 3
More info on 3rd Degree Polynomials is here: http://id.mind.net/~zona/mmts/functionInstitute/polynomialFunctions/graphs/degree3PolynomialFunction.html
But I do not understand about the "three real roots from the equations of three lines". I do know how to graph equations though. Can anyone please help?

item.dc:creator: @Teh_Freak Teh Freak
item.description:
@Teh_Freak wrote:

Imaginary (“complex”) numbers, are gay, i never liked them, and they are never used anywhere, unless you’re a teacher, im taking AP Stat right now, its not even math, but its a different way of approaching data, its like number crunching, i like it alot, but i dont put forth the effort i could, but meh, im still passing

item.description:
@Ron wrote:

exps35:

oh, and whats the big proj ron? Im only 3 weeks into school right now so none of that crap for me yet except I have a huge research paper on plagurism and people who got busted for it on a high scale (theres some guy who made 10 grand off selling his old papers, and got busted :P)

I got a 98 on the project. The project was on Emotional Intelligence for Health class.

It was 3 am when I finished it, and I looked at the time, said oh shit, and fell asleep on the couch, so I couldn’t get to the problem of the week lol.

Ahh well, thanks everyone for helping though. Really nice.

item.title: Pre Calculus help
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

That’s a better method than mine Teh Freak

But in regard to solving for 2 complex numbers and 1 real, my method was better imo. You start out with a quadratic that WILL give you complex solutions…ie in ax^2 + bx + c, 4ac > b^2. From there, you can add another x outside (or binomial) and you get your cubic.

I forget how to do 3 though right now…its late though so I’ll think again tomorrow

Read full topic

item.title: Pre Calculus help
item.dc:creator: @Teh_Freak Teh Freak
item.description:
@Teh_Freak wrote:

you work backwards, with a 3 you have like, (x+1)(x+2)(x+3) and solve out for that

(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)

(x^2+3x+2)(x+3)

x^3+x^2+3x^2+9x+2x+6

x^3 + 4x^2+11x+6 would solve out for one with 3 solutions.

thats just basic, #1, but numbers 2 and 3, i forgot how to include imaginary numbers into a problem, it slipped my mind.

Read full topic

Jeez… Ron you know I can’t do that

Read full topic

item.title: Pre Calculus help
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

3rd degree polynomials = cubic btw

And do you mean just constructing the lines and make the cubic out of it, or vice versa? Because thats all I could get out of it. Well if so, number 1 is easy - just create a pure quadratic and factor in an x.

f(x) = x^2 - 4 – quadratic with roots of ±2
g(x) = x(x^2 - 4) = x^3 - 4x – cubic with roots 0, -2, +2

And for the lines, you just need 3 lines that go through those points…first line is easy - x = y. For the other two, you can use slope-point formula to solve:

y = x - 2
y = x + 2

Let me know if this is right and if you need help then with the other two.

Read full topic
